description:
One summer vacation, Ruka meets two boys, "Umi" and "Sora," whose upbringing contains strange and wonderful secrets. Drawn to their beautiful swimming, almost more like flying, Ruka and the adults who know them are intertwined in a complex mesh...
Meanwhile, an unexplained anomaly is occurring all over the world: fish are disappearing. Thus begins a marine adventure of boys and girls to captivate all the senses!

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Primarily Child Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters below a high school age.

tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

tags.name: Environmental
tags.description: Concern with the state of the natural world and how humans interact with it.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.description: Centers around the sport of swimming.

tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Seinen
tags.description: Target demographic is adult males.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Ships
tags.description: Prominently features the use of sea-based transportation vessels.

tags.name: Bullying
tags.description: Prominently features the use of force for intimidation, often in a school setting.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.description: Prominently features a male character who is a part-monster.

tags.description: Relating or centered around the study of celestial objects and phenomena, space, or the universe.

tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.description: Centers around the sport of handball.

tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

node.description:
__[Blog](https://iga-ren.hatenadiary.org) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/igadaioshirase)__

Debuted with Ohayashi ga kikoeru rear in 1994.

Igarashi is known among manga fans for his bold, detailed art style and innovative storytelling. While his works are often described as fantastical, they can hardly be categorized as traditional fantasy stories; instead, Igarashi draws inspiration from folklore and nature combined with surrealism and spiritual themes to create a style that has earned comparisons to the films of Hayao Miyazaki (Igarashi himself stated in an interview that Miyazaki's film My Neighbor Totoro was a key influence on his decision to become a manga artist)

[Website](http://joehisaishi.com/) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCxyzciBLt1Hyw06dlqwAIkw) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/official_joeh) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/joehisaishi.official/)

Mamoru Fujisawa, known professionally as Joe Hisaishi, is a Japanese composer and musical director known for over 100 film scores and solo albums dating back to 1981. He has been associated with filmmaker [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) since 1984, having composed scores for all but one of his films. Hisaishi is also widely known for his piano scores.

While possessing a stylistically distinct sound, Hisaishi's music has been known to explore and incorporate different genres, including minimalist, experimental electronic, European classical, and Japanese classical. Lesser known are the other musical roles he plays; he is also a typesetter, author, arranger, and conductor. Hisaishi was a student of composer [Takeo Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/106839/).

Hisaishi started learning violin in the Violin School Suzuki Shinichi at the age of four, he found his passion in music. At the same age, he also began watching 300 movies a year with his father, which influenced his career. Realizing his love, he attended the Kunitachi College of Music in 1969 to major in music composition. Hisaishi collaborated with minimalist artists as a typesetter, furthering his experience in the musical world.

He enjoyed his first success of the business in 1974 when he composed music for the anime series called [Gyatoruzu](https://anilist.co/anime/8763/). This and other early works were created under his given name. He presented his first public performance in the mid '70s, spreading his name around his community.

In 1983, Hisaishi was recommended to create an image album for [Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](https://anilist.co/anime/572/). Hisaishi and the director of the animated film, Hayao Miyazaki, became great friends and would work together on many future projects. In 1985, he founded his own recording studio—the wonder station. Their collaboration has invited comparisons to the collaborations of Steven Spielberg and John Williams. This big break led to Hisaishi's overwhelming success as a composer of film scores. In 1986, [Laputa: Castle in the Sky](https://anilist.co/anime/513/) would be the first feature to appear under the [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) banner, and its gentle, faintly melancholic tone would become a familiar trademark of much of the studio's later output. As Hisaishi strengthened his reputation as one of the budding anime industry's top musical contributors, his compositions would proceed to become some of the very hallmarks of early anime in the '80s and '90s.

Hisaishi formulated an alias inspired by Quincy Jones, an African-American musician and producer. Re-transcribed in Japanese, "Quincy Jones" became "Joe Hisaishi". ("Quincy", pronounced "Kuinshī” in Japanese, can be written using the same kanji in "Hisaishi"; "Joe" comes from "Jones".)

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%B8%A1%E8%BE%BA%E6%AD%A9)

Ayumu Watanabe is a director, screenwriter, storyboard artist and a former animator.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1025616676341968896)

Shinji Kimura is a renown art director. He has also ventured into directing.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenichi_0623) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小西賢一)

Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).

Noted for his work as a character designer on tiles such as [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/), [Bokurano](https://anilist.co/anime/1690/) and [Children of the Sea](https://anilist.co/anime/103221/).

The president of Studio 4°C, an animation studio she founded with Koji Morimoto and Yoshiharu Sato in 1986. Tanaka is also the chief executive officer of a production company called Beyond C, which initiated the project with Michael Arias that became Tekkon Kinkreet. 

Tanaka was an executive producer on Tekkon Kinkreet and Mind Game, both Studio 4°C films. She was also an animation producer on Beyond and The Second Renaissance Part 1 for the Animatrix project. Tanaka previously worked with Studio Ghibli and played the role of line producer on My Neighbor Totoro and Kiki's Delivery Service.

**Height:** 188 cm

__[Website](http://reissuerecords.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/hachi_08) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/hachi_08/?hl=en)__

Kenshi Yonezu is a Japanese musician who began releasing Vocaloid music under the stage name Hachi in 2009. In 2012 he debuted under his real name, releasing music with his own voice. He produced the remix of the ending song in AnoHana. He went to university for fine arts, so he does his own art for his animated music videos.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenichi_0623) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小西賢一)

Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).

Noted for his work as a character designer on tiles such as [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/), [Bokurano](https://anilist.co/anime/1690/) and [Children of the Sea](https://anilist.co/anime/103221/).
Founder of sound production studio Digital Circus.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenichi_0623) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小西賢一)

Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).

Noted for his work as a character designer on tiles such as [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/), [Bokurano](https://anilist.co/anime/1690/) and [Children of the Sea](https://anilist.co/anime/103221/).

**[Twitter](https://twitter.com/editzhirose)** | **[Website](http://www.editz.jp/)**

**Hirose Kiyoshi** is a Japanese editor and film editor.

Originating from [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/) where he was employed at until the production of [Summer Wars](https://anilist.co/anime/5681/). He is an apprentice of [Takaaki Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/110187/)'s, whose style of animation has strongly influenced him.

Married to [Miyako Kitada](https://anilist.co/staff/167718/).

[Website](http://qbo.sakura.ne.jp/masahiko/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/macha_mkun) | [Flickr](https://www.flickr.com/people/39493978@N08/)

In recent years he has also been working as still photographer.
Freelancer originating from [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/), where he studied under [Tetsuya Nishio](https://anilist.co/staff/103725/).
